div.p:
We heard with real concern
of your unfortunate accident,
& we should have written to you, im
-mediately immediately after we had heard of it
had we not thought that we should
have heard from you, upon another
subject.

I now write for your advice, as a
common friend to us & to your
old house - The want of money
or rather, the want of credit, has
lowered the demand for everything
that is saleable - of course, this
depreciation must affect the sale

of books, as well as of every thing everything
else. -

I informed you that the beginning of this
year, was employed in writing some
plays & tales - With respect to the
latter, it was intended that they should be inter
-spersed interspersed with the plays, to achieve
the attention of the Reader -
but the first of these tales, soon as-
sumed assumed a different character from
that which we had intended - &
has swelled into a volume - which
is in my judgment, inferior to no-
thing nothing that Maria has written -
The story is interesting & the style
marked with her peculiar vivacity
The present state therefore, of our

affair is this - one volume of come
=edies comedies in three acts - & a tale in one
volume; - The comedies have
three times the trouble; of
that writing
the tale has done - but I do not
suppose that they will sell, half
as well. - At the same time, I
am made to understand by Hunter
that it is better to publish two volumes
at a time, than one: - Suppose the title to be as follows -

Comedies in three acts - 1 vol
Harrington a tale - 1 vol.
By Miss Edgeworth

Now we know that Hunter
wd
would .
give any price, we chose to name
for whatever we sent him, - & we
firmly believe, that none of us can

well ascertain the probability of the
sale of any work at present -
I therefore suppose, that, with respect
the volume containing a tale
will be called for separately by
different purchasers. - the demand
for the tale will be far superior to
the demand for the plays - in
consequence each volume should
be valued separately -

Of the value of a tale by Miss E.
there cannot now be much doubt
even, in the present state of things

There certainly has not appeared
any thing new lately in that line
that could eclipse her -
A price therefore may be fixed
upon this volume - but I am inclined
to think, that no price should be fixed
